case_vignette: A 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of tender, red nodules that appeared on his chest 3 days ago. Three weeks ago, he had similar symptoms in his right lower limb and another episode in his left foot; both episodes resolved spontaneously. He also has diarrhea and has had a poor appetite for 1 month. He has a history of dry cough and joint pain, for which he takes albuterol and aspirin as needed. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 15 years. He does not drink alcohol. Physical examination shows a linear, erythematous lesion on the right anterior chest wall, through which a cord-like structure can be palpated. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft, nontender, and non-distended. Examination of the legs is normal. An ultrasound of the legs shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis of the underlying condition?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have sore, red bumps on my chest that appeared 3 days ago.
Have these bumps spread to any other parts of your body?
I had similar symptoms on my right lower limb and my left foot a few weeks ago, but they went away on their own.
Did these bumps blister, ooze, or crust at any point?
No, they did not blister, ooze, or crust.
Do you experience any itching or pain associated with these bumps?
Yes, the bumps are tender.
Do you have any known allergies or recent insect bites?
No, I don't have any known allergies or recent insect bites.
Is there a history of skin conditions like eczema, psoriasis, or similar issues in your family?
I do not know of any skin conditions like eczema or psoriasis in my family.
What is your age and sex?
I am a 49-year-old man.
Have you recently started taking any new medications or supplements?
No, I have not started any new medications or supplements recently.
Have you had any fever, joint pains, or other systemic symptoms?
I have joint pain and a history of dry cough, but no mention of a fever.
Did the joint pain and dry cough occur around the same time as the skin symptoms?
The joint pain is part of my ongoing health history, and I also have a history of dry cough, but it's not specified if they occurred exactly at the same time as the skin symptoms.
Have you recently engaged in any new activities or been exposed to new environments that might have led to these symptoms?
No, I have not engaged in any new activities or been exposed to new environments that might have led to these symptoms.

Considering your age, the appearance of the red bumps, and the recurrent nature of the symptoms without obvious blistering or crusting, I will make a diagnosis. 

**Final Diagnosis: Erythema nodosum.**

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A 49-year-old man visits the clinic with sore, red bumps on his chest that appeared 3 days ago. He had similar symptoms on his right lower limb and left foot a few weeks ago, but they went away on their own. The bumps are tender and have not blistered, oozed, or crusted. He does not have any known allergies or recent insect bites, and there is no history of eczema or psoriasis in his family. He also reports joint pain and a history of dry cough, but there is no mention of a fever. The joint pain is a part of his ongoing health history. He denies having started any new medications or supplements recently, and has not engaged in any new activities or been exposed to new environments that might have led to these symptoms.
trial_0.vignette_frq: Obtain a biopsy of the cord-like chest wall lesion.
trial_0.multiturn_frq: Final Diagnosis: Considering the recurrent nature of tender, red bumps without blistering or known allergies, and in the absence of systemic symptoms such as fever, this presentation could be consistent with Erythema nodosum. However, a thorough physical examination and additional laboratory tests would be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and to investigate underlying causes such as infections, medications, or systemic diseases.
